title: Grazing and Haying Cover Crops with Josh Roe

tasks.task: Attending a presentation on cover crops and their application in agriculture.
subtasks: Understanding the speaker's background and experience in agriculture.
Learning about the benefits of cover crops in different farming practices (grazing, haying, soil fertility, moisture management).
Acknowledging the lack of economic data on cover crop returns and the initiation of a SARE producer grant.
Identifying the study location and its agricultural history (continuous no-till for 15 years with alfalfa, corn, soybeans, and wheat rotations).
Considering the advice of a local seed expert (Dale Strickler) for the cover crop mixture.
Dealing with specific seed mixes for grazing (oats, spring field peas, radishes, turnips, forage sorghum) and haying (without radishes and turnips).
Noting the early planted date (August 6th) and unexpected heavy rainfall (two weeks later) leading to high forage production (18.15 tons per acre wet weight).

Calculating costs associated with cover crop establishment (chemical application, custom drilling, seed) and analyzing net income per ton for hay (1.59 tons per acre yielding $90 value, costs of $73.40 per ton, net $16.66).
Assessing the efficiency of cattle grazing on cover crops (58 head gained 183 pounds over 86 days, total cost under $124 per head, cost per pound of gain $0.68).
Recognizing the field's soil health improvement after grazing and the potential long-term benefits of cover crops.
Addressing weed management concerns (Palmer amaranth) and herbicide considerations for subsequent crops.
Considering the economic impact of supplemental feed (corn gluten pellets) as part of the overall operation.
Evaluating the value of soil health improvements and nutrient contributions from cover crops and livestock manure.
